description.narrative: The tropical cyclone IDAI which affected Mozambique and also the Mavuzi area, mid March 2019, strongly affected the country, the infrastructure, the energy supply and distribution, as well as the completion of the rehabilitation project. The cyclone caused extreme flood event which resulted in over topping of the left and right abutment of the Mavuzi dam, and of the flood gates, thereby causing damage to some of the installations at the dam.The second half of 2019 was dominated by site inspections, cost estimation of the damages caused and close consultation between EDM and development partners (Sweden, German KFW and France AFD) to enact emergency repairs of the dam and the power station in addition to completion of the rehabilitation of the hydro power stations. Up to March, the project was proceeding, albeit some delays but the cyclone caused major disturbance to the works. Damages were severe in some areas especially in Mavusi HPP where cracks on the dam structure were noticed, embankment and roads around the dam were damaged and some iinstallations were also damaged. Several site investigations were carried out and damage reports were produced and costed. Some negotiations were held with the EPC contractors on the damage repairs but were not successful due to very exaggerated cost estimates for the repairs. Development partners approved adding funds to repair the damages (79MSEK AND 4MEUR from KFW). AFD agreed to extend the financial agreement to allow the use of remaining funds. The use of the different funds were agreed during follow up meetings between the stakeholders. It should also be noticed that there were number of conflicts between EDM and the EPC consortium that elevated the involvement of legal experts to solve the issues. EDM and the development partners have had weekly meetings to find resolutions for the different issues. It was finally agreed to break the repairs into several packages to reduce the cost of the repairs. Those were either directly negotiated with the consortium lead Cegelec or decided to be procured separately by EDM following the different procurement modalities with the direct supervision of the EoS. EoS also provided a procurement expert to support those procurement to mitigate the increased procurement risk under the agreed scheme. EoS also decided to have follow up on areas related to human rights approach, gender integration in the project. The procurement of experts were delayed due to COVID-19 but planned to be procured fourth quarter 2020. It should be noted that reporting quality from EDM is below the required standards and EoS is following that issue with EDM closely. Positive steps have been seen in this regards although much left to enable obtaining the required quality. Contact negotiations with the lead contractor were carried out with close monitoring of the development partners. EoS insisted on having number of areas covered under the contract namely, adherence to labour laws including child labour, extended Aids/HIV campaign and support mechanism, sexual conduct included in the contract and insurances to workers on site. Cegelec agreed on all the areas proposed by the embassy and will finance all the activity from own finances (estimated over 500,000Eur).
